title: Getting started with pmsims
text: pmsims estimates minimum sample size needed develop prediction model achieve target level performance assurance. Rather relying simple rules thumb closed‑form formulae, pmsims uses simulation : Generate synthetic datasets reflect target setting (outcome type, prevalence \(R^2\), signal vs. noise predictors); Fit specified model (e.g., logistic regression linear regression); Evaluate chosen performance metric (e.g., calibration slope, AUC); Trace learning curve performance training size increases.  recommended design objective assurance: smallest \(n\) high proportion repeated studies (e.g., 80%) meet target performance. pmsims, implemented via 20th percentile simulated performance distribution \(n\).

title: Getting started with pmsims
text: three wrapper functions binary, continuous, survival outcomes, respectively: simulate_binary() simulate_continuous() simulate_survival() three functions share basic structure. table lists key inputs. Notes: engine automatically tunes data generator chosen model reaches specified large‑sample performance (C‑statistic \(R^2\)) large samples. reproducibility, set random seed (set.seed()).

code: set.seed(123)  binary_example <- simulate_binary(   signal_parameters = 20,   noise_parameters  = 0,   predictor_type = "continuous",   binary_predictor_prevalence = NULL,   outcome_prevalence = 0.30,   large_sample_cstatistic = 0.80,   model = "glm",   metric = "calibration_slope",   minimum_acceptable_performance = 0.85,   n_reps_total = 1000,   mean_or_assurance = "assurance" )  binary_example #>                     ┌────────────────────────────────────────┐ #>                     │ pmsims: Sample size simulation summary │ #>                     └────────────────────────────────────────┘ #> ──────────────────────────────────── Inputs ──────────────────────────────────── #>                                Outcome : binary #>                         Predictor type : continuous #>                   Number of predictors : 20 #>                       Noise predictors : 0 #>                             Prevalence : 0.3 #>      Expected large-sample performance : C-statistic ('cstatistic') = 0.800 #>   Target for chosen performance metric : Calibration slope ('calib_slope') = 0.850 #>                                  Model : glm #>                        Simulation reps : 1,000 #> ──────────────────────────────────── Results ─────────────────────────────────── #>              Final minimum sample size : 1,173 #>             Estimated performance at N : 0.849 (Calibration slope ('calib_slope') = 0.850) #>                                  Model : glm #>                                   Mode : Assurance #>                           Running time : 1 minute #>     Assurance mode ensures the target metric is met with high probability across repeated datasets. plot(binary_example)

title: pmsims
text: pmsims R package estimating much data needed develop reliable generalisable prediction models. uses simulation-based learning curve approach quantify model performance improves increasing sample size, supporting principled study planning feasibility assessment. package fully model-agnostic: users can define data generated, models fitted, predictive performance measured. currently supports regression-based prediction models continuous, binary, time--event outcomes. Developed King’s College London (Department Biostatistics & Health Informatics) input researchers, clinicians, patient partners. See pmsims project site details.

title: The Bisection Engine — calculate_bisection
text: data_function function returns datasets. Must single argument, n, controls sample size. model_function function fits models data. Takes data object returned data_function argument. metric_function function returns performance metric. Must take test data, fitted model model function arguments. Must return single value. value_on_error Numeric fallback returned simulation run fails. min_sample_size Integer lower bound sample-size search region. max_sample_size Integer upper bound sample-size search region. test_n Integer size test datasets used evaluate performance (large). n_reps_total Integer total number simulation replications allocated search. n_reps_per Integer number replications evaluated candidate sample size. target_performance Numeric target performance threshold algorithm must meet exceed. c_statistic Numeric; anticipated large-sample discrimination used tuning data generator. mean_or_assurance Character string "mean" "assurance" indicating criterion defines minimum sample size. tol Numeric tolerance controlling bisection loop stops. parallel Logical; TRUE per-sample-size simulations run parallel via foreach. cores Integer number cores use parallel = TRUE. verbose Logical flag passed mlpwr; TRUE verbose output printed. budget Logical; TRUE algorithm halts evaluation budget exhausted instead using tol.

title: Minimum sample size for binary-outcome prediction models — simulate_binary
text: Two formulations supported. Mean-based: find smallest \(n\) expected model performance exceeds target \(M^*\), .e. $$\min_n \; \mathbb{E}_{D_n}\{ M \mid D_n \} \ge M^*.$$ Assurance-based: find smallest \(n\) probability performance exceeds \(M^*\) least \(\delta\) (e.g. 0.80), .e. $$\min_n \; \mathbb{P}_{D_n}\!\left( M \mid D_n \ge M^* \right) \ge \delta.$$ , \(M\) chosen performance metric probability/expectation repeated samples training data size \(n\). assurance criterion explicitly accounts variability across training sets; models higher variance typically require larger \(n\) satisfy .
